Week 31 | More Than Five Thousand Fed
Mt 14:14-21 Mk 6:33-44 Lk 9:11-17 Jn 6:2-15
Default Mt 14:14-21 Mk 6:33-44 Lk 9:11-17 Jn 6:2-15
MK
6:33
But many people saw them leave and recognized them. So from all the towns they ran to the place where Jesus was going, and they got there before him.
MK
6:34
When he arrived, he saw a great crowd waiting. He felt sorry for them, because they were like sheep without a shepherd. So he began to teach them many things.
MK
6:35
When it was late in the day, his followers came to him and said, “No one lives in this place, and it is already very late.
MK
6:36
Send the people away so they can go to the countryside and towns around here to buy themselves something to eat.”
MT
14:16
But Jesus answered, “They don’t need to go away. You give them something to eat.”
JN
6:7
Philip answered, “Someone would have to work almost a year to buy enough bread for each person to have only a little piece.”
JN
6:8
Another one of his followers, Andrew, Simon Peter’s brother, said,
JN
6:9
“Here is a boy with five loaves of barley bread and two little fish, but that is not enough for so many people.”
LK
9:14
(There were about five thousand men there.) Jesus said to his followers, “Tell the people to sit in groups of about fifty people.”
MK
6:40
So they sat in groups of fifty or a hundred.
MK
6:41
Jesus took the five loaves and two fish and, looking up to heaven, he thanked God for the food. He divided the bread and gave it to his followers for them to give to the people. Then he divided the two fish among them all.
MK
6:42
All the people ate and were satisfied.
JN
6:12
When they had all had enough to eat, Jesus said to his followers, “Gather the leftover pieces of fish and bread so that nothing is wasted.”
JN
6:13
So they gathered up the pieces and filled twelve baskets with the pieces left from the five barley loaves.
JN
6:14
When the people saw this miracle that Jesus did, they said, “He must truly be the Prophet(x) who is coming into the world.”
JN
6:15
Jesus knew that the people planned to come and take him by force and make him their king, so he left and went into the hills alone.
Default Mt 14:14-21 Mk 6:33-44 Lk 9:11-17 Jn 6:2-15
MT
14:14
When he arrived, he saw a great crowd waiting. He felt sorry for them and healed those who were sick.
MT
14:15
When it was evening, his followers came to him and said, “No one lives in this place, and it is already late. Send the people away so they can go to the towns and buy food for themselves.”
MT
14:16
But Jesus answered, “They don’t need to go away. You give them something to eat.”
MT
14:17
They said to him, “But we have only five loaves of bread and two fish.”
MT
14:18
Jesus said, “Bring the bread and the fish to me.”
MT
14:19
Then he told the people to sit down on the grass. He took the five loaves and the two fish and, looking to heaven, he thanked God for the food. Jesus divided the bread and gave it to his followers, who gave it to the people.
MT
14:20
All the people ate and were satisfied. Then the followers filled twelve baskets with the leftover pieces of food.
MT
14:21
There were about five thousand men there who ate, not counting women and children.
Default Mt 14:14-21 Mk 6:33-44 Lk 9:11-17 Jn 6:2-15
MK
6:33
But many people saw them leave and recognized them. So from all the towns they ran to the place where Jesus was going, and they got there before him.
MK
6:34
When he arrived, he saw a great crowd waiting. He felt sorry for them, because they were like sheep without a shepherd. So he began to teach them many things.
MK
6:35
When it was late in the day, his followers came to him and said, “No one lives in this place, and it is already very late.
MK
6:36
Send the people away so they can go to the countryside and towns around here to buy themselves something to eat.”
MK
6:37
But Jesus answered, “You give them something to eat.” They said to him, “We would all have to work a month to earn enough money to buy that much bread!”
MK
6:38
Jesus asked them, “How many loaves of bread do you have? Go and see.” When they found out, they said, “Five loaves and two fish.”
MK
6:39
Then Jesus told his followers to have the people sit in groups on the green grass.
MK
6:40
So they sat in groups of fifty or a hundred.
MK
6:41
Jesus took the five loaves and two fish and, looking up to heaven, he thanked God for the food. He divided the bread and gave it to his followers for them to give to the people. Then he divided the two fish among them all.
MK
6:42
All the people ate and were satisfied.
MK
6:43
The followers filled twelve baskets with the leftover pieces of bread and fish.
MK
6:44
There were five thousand men who ate.
Default Mt 14:14-21 Mk 6:33-44 Lk 9:11-17 Jn 6:2-15
LK
9:11
But the people learned where Jesus went and followed him. He welcomed them and talked with them about God’s kingdom and healed those who needed to be healed.
LK
9:12
Late in the afternoon, the twelve apostles came to Jesus and said, “Send the people away. They need to go to the towns and countryside around here and find places to sleep and something to eat, because no one lives in this place.”
LK
9:13
But Jesus said to them, “You give them something to eat.” They said, “We have only five loaves of bread and two fish, unless we go buy food for all these people.”
LK
9:14
(There were about five thousand men there.) Jesus said to his followers, “Tell the people to sit in groups of about fifty people.”
LK
9:15
So the followers did this, and all the people sat down.
LK
9:16
Then Jesus took the five loaves of bread and two fish, and looking up to heaven, he thanked God for the food. Then he divided the food and gave it to the followers to give to the people.
LK
9:17
They all ate and were satisfied, and what was left over was gathered up, filling twelve baskets.
Default Mt 14:14-21 Mk 6:33-44 Lk 9:11-17 Jn 6:2-15
JN
6:2
Many people followed him because they saw the miracles he did to heal the sick.
JN
6:3
Jesus went up on a hill and sat down there with his followers.
JN
6:4
It was almost the time for the Jewish Passover [Trumpets] Feast.

John 6:4 misidentifies Trumpets as Passover. The event is in Bethsaida, 130+ km away from Jerusalem (at Passover everyone should be in Jerusalem by the Torah). Also, Jesus is feeding the crowd with leavened bread (not allowed at Passover).

JN
6:5
When Jesus looked up and saw a large crowd coming toward him, he said to Philip, “Where can we buy enough bread for all these people to eat?”
JN
6:6
(Jesus asked Philip this question to test him, because Jesus already knew what he planned to do.)
JN
6:7
Philip answered, “Someone would have to work almost a year to buy enough bread for each person to have only a little piece.”
JN
6:8
Another one of his followers, Andrew, Simon Peter’s brother, said,
JN
6:9
“Here is a boy with five loaves of barley bread and two little fish, but that is not enough for so many people.”
JN
6:10
Jesus said, “Tell the people to sit down.” There was plenty of grass there, and about five thousand men sat down there.
JN
6:11
Then Jesus took the loaves of bread, thanked God for them, and gave them to the people who were sitting there. He did the same with the fish, giving as much as the people wanted.
JN
6:12
When they had all had enough to eat, Jesus said to his followers, “Gather the leftover pieces of fish and bread so that nothing is wasted.”
JN
6:13
So they gathered up the pieces and filled twelve baskets with the pieces left from the five barley loaves.
JN
6:14
When the people saw this miracle that Jesus did, they said, “He must truly be the Prophet(x) who is coming into the world.”
JN
6:15
Jesus knew that the people planned to come and take him by force and make him their king, so he left and went into the hills alone.
Week 31 | Jesus And Peter Walks On The Lake
Mt 14:22-36 Mk 6:45-56 Jn 6:16-21
Default Mt 14:22-36 Mk 6:45-56 Jn 6:16-21
MT
14:22
Immediately Jesus told his followers to get into the boat and go ahead of him across the lake. He stayed there to send the people home.
MT
14:23
After he had sent them away, he went by himself up into the hills to pray. It was late, and Jesus was there alone.
MT
14:24
By this time, the boat was already far away from land. It was being hit by waves, because the wind was blowing against it.
MT
14:25
Between three and six o’clock in the morning, Jesus came to them, walking on the water.
MT
14:26
When his followers saw him walking on the water, they were afraid. They said, “It’s a ghost!” and cried out in fear.
MT
14:27
But Jesus quickly spoke to them, “Have courage! It is I. Do not be afraid.”
MT
14:28
Peter said, “Lord, if it is really you, then command me to come to you on the water.”
MT
14:29
Jesus said, “Come.” And Peter left the boat and walked on the water to Jesus.
MT
14:30
But when Peter saw the wind and the waves, he became afraid and began to sink. He shouted, “Lord, save me!”
MT
14:31
Immediately Jesus reached out his hand and caught Peter. Jesus said, “Your faith is small. Why did you doubt?”
MT
14:32
After they got into the boat, the wind became calm.
MT
14:33
Then those who were in the boat worshiped Jesus and said, “Truly you are the Son of God!”
MK
6:52
They did not understand about the miracle of the five loaves, because their minds were closed.
MT
14:34
When they had crossed the lake, they came to shore at Gennesaret.
MT
14:35
When the people there recognized Jesus, they told people all around there that Jesus had come, and they brought all their sick to him.
MT
14:36
They begged Jesus to let them touch just the edge of his coat, and all who touched it were healed.
Default Mt 14:22-36 Mk 6:45-56 Jn 6:16-21
MT
14:22
Immediately Jesus told his followers to get into the boat and go ahead of him across the lake. He stayed there to send the people home.
MT
14:23
After he had sent them away, he went by himself up into the hills to pray. It was late, and Jesus was there alone.
MT
14:24
By this time, the boat was already far away from land. It was being hit by waves, because the wind was blowing against it.
MT
14:25
Between three and six o’clock in the morning, Jesus came to them, walking on the water.
MT
14:26
When his followers saw him walking on the water, they were afraid. They said, “It’s a ghost!” and cried out in fear.
MT
14:27
But Jesus quickly spoke to them, “Have courage! It is I. Do not be afraid.”
MT
14:28
Peter said, “Lord, if it is really you, then command me to come to you on the water.”
MT
14:29
Jesus said, “Come.” And Peter left the boat and walked on the water to Jesus.
MT
14:30
But when Peter saw the wind and the waves, he became afraid and began to sink. He shouted, “Lord, save me!”
MT
14:31
Immediately Jesus reached out his hand and caught Peter. Jesus said, “Your faith is small. Why did you doubt?”
MT
14:32
After they got into the boat, the wind became calm.
MT
14:33
Then those who were in the boat worshiped Jesus and said, “Truly you are the Son of God!”
MT
14:34
When they had crossed the lake, they came to shore at Gennesaret.
MT
14:35
When the people there recognized Jesus, they told people all around there that Jesus had come, and they brought all their sick to him.
MT
14:36
They begged Jesus to let them touch just the edge of his coat, and all who touched it were healed.
Default Mt 14:22-36 Mk 6:45-56 Jn 6:16-21
MK
6:45
Immediately Jesus told his followers to get into the boat and go ahead of him to Bethsaida across the lake. He stayed there to send the people home.
MK
6:46
After sending them away, he went into the hills to pray.
MK
6:47
That night, the boat was in the middle of the lake, and Jesus was alone on the land.
MK
6:48
He saw his followers struggling hard to row the boat, because the wind was blowing against them. Between three and six o’clock in the morning, Jesus came to them, walking on the water, and he wanted to walk past the boat.
MK
6:49
But when they saw him walking on the water, they thought he was a ghost and cried out.
MK
6:50
They all saw him and were afraid. But quickly Jesus spoke to them and said, “Have courage! It is I. Do not be afraid.”
MK
6:51
Then he got into the boat with them, and the wind became calm. The followers were greatly amazed.
MK
6:52
They did not understand about the miracle of the five loaves, because their minds were closed.
MK
6:53
When they had crossed the lake, they came to shore at Gennesaret and tied the boat there.
MK
6:54
When they got out of the boat, people immediately recognized Jesus.
MK
6:55
They ran everywhere in that area and began to bring sick people on mats wherever they heard he was.
MK
6:56
And everywhere he went-into towns, cities, or countryside-the people brought the sick to the marketplaces. They begged him to let them touch just the edge of his coat, and all who touched it were healed.
Default Mt 14:22-36 Mk 6:45-56 Jn 6:16-21
JN
6:16
That evening Jesus’ followers went down to Lake Galilee.
JN
6:17
It was dark now, and Jesus had not yet come to them. The followers got into a boat and started across the lake to Capernaum.
JN
6:18
By now a strong wind was blowing, and the waves on the lake were getting bigger.
JN
6:19
When they had rowed the boat about three or four miles, they saw Jesus walking on the water, coming toward the boat. The followers were afraid,
JN
6:20
but Jesus said to them, “It is I. Do not be afraid.”
JN
6:21
Then they were glad to take him into the boat. At once the boat came to land at the place where they wanted to go.
Week 31 | Feast Of The Day Of Trumpets
Jn 6:22-71
Jn 6:22-71
JN
6:22
The next day the people who had stayed on the other side of the lake knew that Jesus had not gone in the boat with his followers but that they had left without him. And they knew that only one boat had been there.
JN
6:23
But then some boats came from Tiberias and landed near the place where the people had eaten the bread after the Lord had given thanks.
JN
6:24
When the people saw that Jesus and his followers were not there now, they got into boats and went to Capernaum to find Jesus.
JN
6:25
When the people found Jesus on the other side of the lake, they asked him, “Teacher, when did you come here?”
JN
6:26
Jesus answered, “I tell you the truth, you aren’t looking for me because you saw me do miracles. You are looking for me because you ate the bread and were satisfied.
JN
6:27
Don’t work for the food that spoils. Work for the food that stays good always and gives eternal life. The Son of Man will give you this food, because on him God the Father has put his power.”
JN
6:28
The people asked Jesus, “What are the things God wants us to do?”
JN
6:29
Jesus answered, “The work God wants you to do is this: Believe the One he sent.”
JN
6:30
So the people asked, “What miracle will you do? If we see a miracle, we will believe you. What will you do?
JN
6:31
Our ancestors ate the manna in the desert. This is written in the Scriptures: ‘He gave them bread from heaven to eat.’”(y)
JN
6:32
Jesus said, “I tell you the truth, it was not Moses who gave you bread from heaven; it is my Father who is giving you the true bread from heaven.
JN
6:33
God’s bread is the One who comes down from heaven and gives life to the world.”
JN
6:34
The people said, “Sir, give us this bread always.”
JN
6:35
Then Jesus said, “I am the bread that gives life. Whoever comes to me will never be hungry, and whoever believes in me will never be thirsty.
JN
6:36
But as I told you before, you have seen me and still don’t believe.
JN
6:37
The Father gives me the people who are mine. Every one of them will come to me, and I will always accept them.
JN
6:38
I came down from heaven to do what God wants me to do, not what I want to do.
JN
6:39
Here is what the One who sent me wants me to do: I must not lose even one whom God gave me, but I must raise them all on the last day.
JN
6:40
Those who see the Son and believe in him have eternal life, and I will raise them on the last day. This is what my Father wants.”
JN
6:41
Some people began to complain about Jesus because he said, “I am the bread that comes down from heaven.”
JN
6:42
They said, “This is Jesus, the son of Joseph. We know his father and mother. How can he say, ‘I came down from heaven’?”
JN
6:43
But Jesus answered, “Stop complaining to each other.
JN
6:44
The Father is the One who sent me. No one can come to me unless the Father draws him to me, and I will raise that person up on the last day.
JN
6:45
It is written in the prophets, ‘They will all be taught by God.’(z) Everyone who listens to the Father and learns from him comes to me.
JN
6:46
No one has seen the Father except the One who is from God; only he has seen the Father.
JN
6:47
I tell you the truth, whoever believes has eternal life.
JN
6:48
I am the bread that gives life.
JN
6:49
Your ancestors ate the manna in the desert, but still they died.
JN
6:50
Here is the bread that comes down from heaven. Anyone who eats this bread will never die.
JN
6:51
I am the living bread that came down from heaven. Anyone who eats this bread will live forever. This bread is my flesh, which I will give up so that the world may have life.”
JN
6:52
Then the evil people began to argue among themselves, saying, “How can this man give us his flesh to eat?”
JN
6:53
Jesus said, “I tell you the truth, you must eat the flesh of the Son of Man and drink his blood. Otherwise, you won’t have real life in you.
JN
6:54
Those who eat my flesh and drink my blood have eternal life, and I will raise them up on the last day.
JN
6:55
My flesh is true food, and my blood is true drink.
JN
6:56
Those who eat my flesh and drink my blood live in me, and I live in them.
JN
6:57
The living Father sent me, and I live because of the Father. So whoever eats me will live because of me.
JN
6:58
I am not like the bread your ancestors ate. They ate that bread and still died. I am the bread that came down from heaven, and whoever eats this bread will live forever.”
JN
6:59
Jesus said all these things while he was teaching in the synagogue in Capernaum.
JN
6:60
When the followers of Jesus heard this, many of them said, “This teaching is hard. Who can accept it?”
JN
6:61
Knowing that his followers were complaining about this, Jesus said, “Does this teaching bother you?
JN
6:62
Then will it also bother you to see the Son of Man going back to the place where he came from?
JN
6:63
It is the Spirit that gives life. The flesh doesn’t give life. The words I told you are spirit, and they give life.
JN
6:64
But some of you don’t believe.” (Jesus knew from the beginning who did not believe and who would turn against him.)
JN
6:65
Jesus said, “That is the reason I said, ‘If the Father does not bring a person to me, that one cannot come.’”
JN
6:66
After Jesus said this, many of his followers left him and stopped following him.
JN
6:67
Jesus asked the twelve followers, “Do you want to leave, too?”
JN
6:68
Simon Peter answered him, “Lord, who would we go to? You have the words that give eternal life.
JN
6:69
We believe and know that you are the Holy One from God.”
JN
6:70
Then Jesus answered, “I chose all twelve of you, but one of you is a devil.”
JN
6:71
Jesus was talking about Judas, the son of Simon Iscariot. Judas was one of the twelve, but later he was going to turn against Jesus.

John 6:4 misidentifies Trumpets as Passover. The Last Day and People's Resurrection are themes of Feast of Trumpets, not Passover

Week 31 | Hypocrite Hand Wash
Mt 15:1-20 Mk 7:1-23 Lk 11:37-54
Default Mt 15:1-20 Mk 7:1-23 Lk 11:37-54
MK
7:1
When some Pharisees and some teachers of the law came from Jerusalem, they gathered around Jesus.
MK
7:2
They saw that some of Jesus’ followers ate food with hands that were not clean, that is, they hadn’t washed them.
MK
7:3
(The Pharisees and all the Jews never eat before washing their hands in the way required by their unwritten laws.
MK
7:4
And when they buy something in the market, they never eat it until they wash themselves in a special way. They also follow many other unwritten laws, such as the washing of cups, pitchers, and pots.(s))
MK
7:5
The Pharisees and the teachers of the law said to Jesus, “Why don’t your followers obey the unwritten laws which have been handed down to us? Why do your followers eat their food with hands that are not clean?”
MT
15:3
Jesus answered, “And why do you refuse to obey God’s command so that you can follow your own teachings?
MT
15:4
God said, ‘Honor your father and your mother,’(at) and ‘Anyone who says cruel things to his father or mother must be put to death.’(au)
MT
15:5
But you say a person can tell his father or mother, ‘I have something I could use to help you, but I have given it to God already.’
MT
15:6
You teach that person not to honor his father or his mother. You rejected what God said for the sake of your own rules.
MT
15:7
You are hypocrites! Isaiah was right when he said about you:
MT
15:8
‘These people show honor to me with words, but their hearts are far from me.
MT
15:9
Their worship of me is worthless. The things they teach are nothing but human rules.’” (Isaiah 29:13)
MK
7:15
There is nothing people put into their bodies that makes them unclean. People are made unclean by the things that come out of them. [
LK
11:40
You foolish people! The same one who made what is outside also made what is inside.
LK
11:41
So give what is in your dishes to the poor, and then you will be fully clean.
LK
11:42
How terrible for you Pharisees! You give God one-tenth of even your mint, your rue, and every other plant in your garden. But you fail to be fair to others and to love God. These are the things you should do while continuing to do those other things.
LK
11:43
How terrible for you Pharisees, because you love to have the most important seats in the synagogues, and you love to be greeted with respect in the marketplaces.
LK
11:44
How terrible for you, because you are like hidden graves, which people walk on without knowing.”
LK
11:45
One of the experts on the law said to Jesus, “Teacher, when you say these things, you are insulting us, too.”
LK
11:46
Jesus answered, “How terrible for you, you experts on the law! You make strict rules that are very hard for people to obey, but you yourselves don’t even try to follow those rules.
LK
11:47
How terrible for you, because you build tombs for the prophets whom your ancestors killed!
LK
11:48
And now you show that you approve of what your ancestors did. They killed the prophets, and you build tombs for them!
LK
11:49
This is why in his wisdom God said, ‘I will send prophets and apostles to them. They will kill some, and they will treat others cruelly.’
LK
11:50
So you who live now will be punished for the deaths of all the prophets who were killed since the beginning of the world-
LK
11:51
from the killing of Abel to the killing of Zechariah,(ay) who died between the altar and the Temple. Yes, I tell you that you who are alive now will be punished for them all.
LK
11:52
“How terrible for you, you experts on the law. You have taken away the key to learning about God. You yourselves would not learn, and you stopped others from learning, too.”
LK
11:53
When Jesus left, the teachers of the law and the Pharisees began to give him trouble, asking him questions about many things,
LK
11:54
trying to catch him saying something wrong.
MT
15:12
Then his followers came to him and asked, “Do you know that the Pharisees are angry because of what you said?”
MT
15:13
Jesus answered, “Every plant that my Father in heaven has not planted himself will be pulled up by the roots.
MT
15:14
Stay away from the Pharisees; they are blind leaders.(av) And if a blind person leads a blind person, both will fall into a ditch.”
MT
15:15
Peter said, “Explain the example to us.”
MT
15:16
Jesus said, “Do you still not understand?
MT
15:17
Surely you know that all the food that enters the mouth goes into the stomach and then goes out of the body.
MT
15:18
But what people say with their mouths comes from the way they think; these are the things that make people unclean.
MT
15:19
Out of the mind come evil thoughts, murder, adultery, sexual sins, stealing, lying, and speaking evil of others.
MT
15:20
These things make people unclean; eating with unwashed hands does not make them unclean.”
Default Mt 15:1-20 Mk 7:1-23 Lk 11:37-54
MT
15:1
Then some Pharisees and teachers of the law came to Jesus from Jerusalem. They asked him,
MT
15:2
“Why don’t your followers obey the unwritten laws which have been handed down to us? They don’t wash their hands before they eat.”
MT
15:3
Jesus answered, “And why do you refuse to obey God’s command so that you can follow your own teachings?
MT
15:4
God said, ‘Honor your father and your mother,’(at) and ‘Anyone who says cruel things to his father or mother must be put to death.’(au)
MT
15:5
But you say a person can tell his father or mother, ‘I have something I could use to help you, but I have given it to God already.’
MT
15:6
You teach that person not to honor his father or his mother. You rejected what God said for the sake of your own rules.
MT
15:7
You are hypocrites! Isaiah was right when he said about you:
MT
15:8
‘These people show honor to me with words, but their hearts are far from me.
MT
15:9
Their worship of me is worthless. The things they teach are nothing but human rules.’” (Isaiah 29:13)
MT
15:10
After Jesus called the crowd to him, he said, “Listen and understand what I am saying.
MT
15:11
It is not what people put into their mouths that makes them unclean. It is what comes out of their mouths that makes them unclean.”
MT
15:12
Then his followers came to him and asked, “Do you know that the Pharisees are angry because of what you said?”
MT
15:13
Jesus answered, “Every plant that my Father in heaven has not planted himself will be pulled up by the roots.
MT
15:14
Stay away from the Pharisees; they are blind leaders.(av) And if a blind person leads a blind person, both will fall into a ditch.”
MT
15:15
Peter said, “Explain the example to us.”
MT
15:16
Jesus said, “Do you still not understand?
MT
15:17
Surely you know that all the food that enters the mouth goes into the stomach and then goes out of the body.
MT
15:18
But what people say with their mouths comes from the way they think; these are the things that make people unclean.
MT
15:19
Out of the mind come evil thoughts, murder, adultery, sexual sins, stealing, lying, and speaking evil of others.
MT
15:20
These things make people unclean; eating with unwashed hands does not make them unclean.”
Default Mt 15:1-20 Mk 7:1-23 Lk 11:37-54
MK
7:1
When some Pharisees and some teachers of the law came from Jerusalem, they gathered around Jesus.
MK
7:2
They saw that some of Jesus’ followers ate food with hands that were not clean, that is, they hadn’t washed them.
MK
7:3
(The Pharisees and all the Jews never eat before washing their hands in the way required by their unwritten laws.
MK
7:4
And when they buy something in the market, they never eat it until they wash themselves in a special way. They also follow many other unwritten laws, such as the washing of cups, pitchers, and pots.(s))
MK
7:5
The Pharisees and the teachers of the law said to Jesus, “Why don’t your followers obey the unwritten laws which have been handed down to us? Why do your followers eat their food with hands that are not clean?”
MK
7:6
Jesus answered, “Isaiah was right when he spoke about you hypocrites. He wrote, ‘These people show honor to me with words, but their hearts are far from me.
MK
7:7
Their worship of me is worthless. The things they teach are nothing but human rules.’ (Isaiah 29:13)
MK
7:8
You have stopped following the commands of God, and you follow only human teachings.”(t)
MK
7:9
Then Jesus said to them, “You cleverly ignore the commands of God so you can follow your own teachings.
MK
7:10
Moses said, ‘Honor your father and your mother,’(u) and ‘Anyone who says cruel things to his father or mother must be put to death.’(v)
MK
7:11
But you say a person can tell his father or mother, ‘I have something I could use to help you, but it is Corban-a gift to God.’
MK
7:12
You no longer let that person use that money for his father or his mother.
MK
7:13
By your own rules, which you teach people, you are rejecting what God said. And you do many things like that.”
MK
7:14
After Jesus called the crowd to him again, he said, “Every person should listen to me and understand what I am saying.
MK
7:15
There is nothing people put into their bodies that makes them unclean. People are made unclean by the things that come out of them. [
MK
7:16
Let those with ears use them and listen.]”(w)
MK
7:17
When Jesus left the people and went into the house, his followers asked him about this story.
MK
7:18
Jesus said, “Do you still not understand? Surely you know that nothing that enters someone from the outside can make that person unclean.
MK
7:19
It does not go into the mind, but into the stomach. Then it goes out of the body.” (When Jesus said this, he meant that no longer was any food unclean for people to eat.)
MK
7:20
And Jesus said, “The things that come out of people are the things that make them unclean.
MK
7:21
All these evil things begin inside people, in the mind: evil thoughts, sexual sins, stealing, murder, adultery,
MK
7:22
greed, evil actions, lying, doing sinful things, jealousy, speaking evil of others, pride, and foolish living.
MK
7:23
All these evil things come from inside and make people unclean.”
Default Mt 15:1-20 Mk 7:1-23 Lk 11:37-54
LK
11:37
After Jesus had finished speaking, a Pharisee asked Jesus to eat with him. So Jesus went in and sat at the table.
LK
11:38
But the Pharisee was surprised when he saw that Jesus did not wash his hands(ax) before the meal.
LK
11:39
The Lord said to him, “You Pharisees clean the outside of the cup and the dish, but inside you are full of greed and evil.
LK
11:40
You foolish people! The same one who made what is outside also made what is inside.
LK
11:41
So give what is in your dishes to the poor, and then you will be fully clean.
LK
11:42
How terrible for you Pharisees! You give God one-tenth of even your mint, your rue, and every other plant in your garden. But you fail to be fair to others and to love God. These are the things you should do while continuing to do those other things.
LK
11:43
How terrible for you Pharisees, because you love to have the most important seats in the synagogues, and you love to be greeted with respect in the marketplaces.
LK
11:44
How terrible for you, because you are like hidden graves, which people walk on without knowing.”
LK
11:45
One of the experts on the law said to Jesus, “Teacher, when you say these things, you are insulting us, too.”
LK
11:46
Jesus answered, “How terrible for you, you experts on the law! You make strict rules that are very hard for people to obey, but you yourselves don’t even try to follow those rules.
LK
11:47
How terrible for you, because you build tombs for the prophets whom your ancestors killed!
LK
11:48
And now you show that you approve of what your ancestors did. They killed the prophets, and you build tombs for them!
LK
11:49
This is why in his wisdom God said, ‘I will send prophets and apostles to them. They will kill some, and they will treat others cruelly.’
LK
11:50
So you who live now will be punished for the deaths of all the prophets who were killed since the beginning of the world-
LK
11:51
from the killing of Abel to the killing of Zechariah,(ay) who died between the altar and the Temple. Yes, I tell you that you who are alive now will be punished for them all.
LK
11:52
“How terrible for you, you experts on the law. You have taken away the key to learning about God. You yourselves would not learn, and you stopped others from learning, too.”

11:53

LK
11:54
trying to catch him saying something wrong.

Week 31 | Herod Hears About Jesus
Mt 14:1-2 Mk 6:14-16 Lk 9:7-9
Default Mt 14:1-2 Mk 6:14-16 Lk 9:7-9
LK
9:7
Herod, the governor, heard about all the things that were happening and was confused, because some people said, “John the Baptist has risen from the dead.”
LK
9:8
Others said, “Elijah has come to us.” And still others said, “One of the prophets who lived long ago has risen from the dead.”
LK
9:9
Herod said, “I cut off John’s head, so who is this man I hear such things about?” And Herod kept trying to see Jesus.
Default Mt 14:1-2 Mk 6:14-16 Lk 9:7-9
MT
14:1
At that time Herod, the ruler of Galilee, heard the reports about Jesus.
MT
14:2
So he said to his servants, “Jesus is John the Baptist, who has risen from the dead. That is why he can work these miracles.”
Default Mt 14:1-2 Mk 6:14-16 Lk 9:7-9
MK
6:14
King Herod heard about Jesus, because he was now well known. Some people said,(p) “He is John the Baptist, who has risen from the dead. That is why he can work these miracles.”
MK
6:15
Others said, “He is Elijah.”(q) Other people said, “Jesus is a prophet, like the prophets who lived long ago.”
MK
6:16
When Herod heard this, he said, “I killed John by cutting off his head. Now he has risen from the dead!”
Default Mt 14:1-2 Mk 6:14-16 Lk 9:7-9
LK
9:7
Herod, the governor, heard about all the things that were happening and was confused, because some people said, “John the Baptist has risen from the dead.”
LK
9:8
Others said, “Elijah has come to us.” And still others said, “One of the prophets who lived long ago has risen from the dead.”
LK
9:9
Herod said, “I cut off John’s head, so who is this man I hear such things about?” And Herod kept trying to see Jesus.
Week 32 | More Than Four Thousand Fed
Mt 15:32-39 Mk 8:1-10
Default Mt 15:32-39 Mk 8:1-10
MK
8:1
Another time there was a great crowd with Jesus that had nothing to eat. So Jesus called his followers and said,
MK
8:2
“I feel sorry for these people, because they have already been with me for three days, and they have nothing to eat.
MK
8:3
If I send them home hungry, they will faint on the way. Some of them live a long way from here.”
MK
8:4
Jesus’ followers answered, “How can we get enough bread to feed all these people? We are far away from any town.”
MT
15:34
Jesus asked, “How many loaves of bread do you have?” They answered, “Seven, and a few small fish.”
MT
15:35
Jesus told the people to sit on the ground.
MT
15:36
He took the seven loaves of bread and the fish and gave thanks to God. Then he divided the food and gave it to his followers, and they gave it to the people.
MT
15:37
All the people ate and were satisfied. Then his followers filled seven baskets with the leftover pieces of food.
MT
15:38
There were about four thousand men there who ate, besides women and children.
MT
15:39
After sending the people home, Jesus got into the boat and went to the area of Magadan.
Default Mt 15:32-39 Mk 8:1-10
MT
15:32
Jesus called his followers to him and said, “I feel sorry for these people, because they have already been with me three days, and they have nothing to eat. I don’t want to send them away hungry. They might faint while going home.”
MT
15:33
His followers asked him, “How can we get enough bread to feed all these people? We are far away from any town.”
MT
15:34
Jesus asked, “How many loaves of bread do you have?” They answered, “Seven, and a few small fish.”
MT
15:35
Jesus told the people to sit on the ground.
MT
15:36
He took the seven loaves of bread and the fish and gave thanks to God. Then he divided the food and gave it to his followers, and they gave it to the people.
MT
15:37
All the people ate and were satisfied. Then his followers filled seven baskets with the leftover pieces of food.
MT
15:38
There were about four thousand men there who ate, besides women and children.
MT
15:39
After sending the people home, Jesus got into the boat and went to the area of Magadan.
Default Mt 15:32-39 Mk 8:1-10
MK
8:1
Another time there was a great crowd with Jesus that had nothing to eat. So Jesus called his followers and said,
MK
8:2
“I feel sorry for these people, because they have already been with me for three days, and they have nothing to eat.
MK
8:3
If I send them home hungry, they will faint on the way. Some of them live a long way from here.”
MK
8:4
Jesus’ followers answered, “How can we get enough bread to feed all these people? We are far away from any town.”
MK
8:5
Jesus asked, “How many loaves of bread do you have?” They answered, “Seven.”
MK
8:6
Jesus told the people to sit on the ground. Then he took the seven loaves, gave thanks to God, and divided the bread. He gave the pieces to his followers to give to the people, and they did so.
MK
8:7
The followers also had a few small fish. After Jesus gave thanks for the fish, he told his followers to give them to the people also.
MK
8:8
All the people ate and were satisfied. Then his followers filled seven baskets with the leftover pieces of food.
MK
8:9
There were about four thousand people who ate. After they had eaten, Jesus sent them home.
MK
8:10
Then right away he got into a boat with his followers and went to the area of Dalmanutha.
Week 32 | Beware Of The Yeast Of The Pharisees
Mt 16:1-12 Mk 8:11-21
Default Mt 16:1-12 Mk 8:11-21
MT
16:1
The Pharisees and Sadducees came to Jesus, wanting to trick him. So they asked him to show them a miracle from God.
MT
16:2
Jesus answered,(aw) “At sunset you say we will have good weather, because the sky is red.
MT
16:3
And in the morning you say that it will be a rainy day, because the sky is dark and red. You see these signs in the sky and know what they mean. In the same way, you see the things that I am doing now, but you don’t know their meaning.
MK
8:12
Jesus sighed deeply and said, “Why do you people ask for a miracle as a sign? I tell you the truth, no sign will be given to you.”
MK
8:13
Then Jesus left the Pharisees and went in the boat to the other side of the lake.
MK
8:14
His followers had only one loaf of bread with them in the boat; they had forgotten to bring more.
MK
8:15
Jesus warned them, “Be careful! Beware of the yeast of the Pharisees and the yeast of Herod.”
MK
8:16
His followers discussed the meaning of this, saying, “He said this because we have no bread.”
MK
8:17
Knowing what they were talking about, Jesus asked them, “Why are you talking about not having bread? Do you still not see or understand? Are your minds closed?
MK
8:18
You have eyes, but you don’t really see. You have ears, but you don’t really listen. Remember when
MK
8:19
I divided five loaves of bread for the five thousand? How many baskets did you fill with leftover pieces of food?” They answered, “Twelve.”
MK
8:20
“And when I divided seven loaves of bread for the four thousand, how many baskets did you fill with leftover pieces of food?” They answered, “Seven.”
MT
16:11
I was not talking to you about bread. Why don’t you understand that? I am telling you to beware of the yeast of the Pharisees and the Sadducees.”
MT
16:12
Then the followers understood that Jesus was not telling them to beware of the yeast used in bread but to beware of the teaching of the Pharisees and the Sadducees.
Default Mt 16:1-12 Mk 8:11-21
MT
16:1
The Pharisees and Sadducees came to Jesus, wanting to trick him. So they asked him to show them a miracle from God.
MT
16:2
Jesus answered,(aw) “At sunset you say we will have good weather, because the sky is red.
MT
16:3
And in the morning you say that it will be a rainy day, because the sky is dark and red. You see these signs in the sky and know what they mean. In the same way, you see the things that I am doing now, but you don’t know their meaning.
MT
16:4
Evil and sinful people ask for a miracle as a sign, but they will not be given any sign, except the sign of Jonah.”(ax) Then Jesus left them and went away.
MT
16:5
Jesus’ followers went across the lake, but they had forgotten to bring bread.
MT
16:6
Jesus said to them, “Be careful! Beware of the yeast of the Pharisees and the Sadducees.”
MT
16:7
His followers discussed the meaning of this, saying, “He said this because we forgot to bring bread.”
MT
16:8
Knowing what they were talking about, Jesus asked them, “Why are you talking about not having bread? Your faith is small.
MT
16:9
Do you still not understand? Remember the five loaves of bread that fed the five thousand? And remember that you filled many baskets with the leftovers?
MT
16:10
Or the seven loaves of bread that fed the four thousand and the many baskets you filled then also?
MT
16:11
I was not talking to you about bread. Why don’t you understand that? I am telling you to beware of the yeast of the Pharisees and the Sadducees.”
MT
16:12
Then the followers understood that Jesus was not telling them to beware of the yeast used in bread but to beware of the teaching of the Pharisees and the Sadducees.
Default Mt 16:1-12 Mk 8:11-21
MK
8:11
The Pharisees came to Jesus and began to ask him questions. Hoping to trap him, they asked Jesus for a miracle from God.
MK
8:12
Jesus sighed deeply and said, “Why do you people ask for a miracle as a sign? I tell you the truth, no sign will be given to you.”
MK
8:13
Then Jesus left the Pharisees and went in the boat to the other side of the lake.
MK
8:14
His followers had only one loaf of bread with them in the boat; they had forgotten to bring more.
MK
8:15
Jesus warned them, “Be careful! Beware of the yeast of the Pharisees and the yeast of Herod.”
MK
8:16
His followers discussed the meaning of this, saying, “He said this because we have no bread.”
MK
8:17
Knowing what they were talking about, Jesus asked them, “Why are you talking about not having bread? Do you still not see or understand? Are your minds closed?
MK
8:18
You have eyes, but you don’t really see. You have ears, but you don’t really listen. Remember when
MK
8:19
I divided five loaves of bread for the five thousand? How many baskets did you fill with leftover pieces of food?” They answered, “Twelve.”
MK
8:20
“And when I divided seven loaves of bread for the four thousand, how many baskets did you fill with leftover pieces of food?” They answered, “Seven.”
MK
8:21
Then Jesus said to them, “Don’t you understand yet?”
Week 32 | Jesus Heals A Blind Man
Mk 8:22-26
Mk 8:22-26
MK
8:22
Jesus and his followers came to Bethsaida. There some people brought a blind man to Jesus and begged him to touch the man.
MK
8:23
So Jesus took the blind man’s hand and led him out of the village. Then he spit on the man’s eyes and put his hands on the man and asked, “Can you see now?”
MK
8:24
The man looked up and said, “Yes, I see people, but they look like trees walking around.”
MK
8:25
Again Jesus put his hands on the man’s eyes. Then the man opened his eyes wide and they were healed, and he was able to see everything clearly.
MK
8:26
Jesus told him to go home, saying, “Don’t go into the town.”(z)
Week 32-33 | Day Of Atonement In Caesarea Philippi
– +
Week 32 | Peter Says Jesus Is The Savior
Mt 16:13-27 Mk 8:27-38 Lk 9:18-26
Default Mt 16:13-27 Mk 8:27-38 Lk 9:18-26
MK
8:27
Jesus and his followers went to the towns around Caesarea Philippi. While they were traveling, Jesus asked them, “Who do people say I am?”
MT
16:14
They answered, “Some say you are John the Baptist. Others say you are Elijah, and still others say you are Jeremiah or one of the prophets.”
MT
16:15
Then Jesus asked them, “And who do you say I am?”
MT
16:16
Simon Peter answered, “You are the Christ, the Son of the living God.”
MT
16:17
Jesus answered, “You are blessed, Simon son of Jonah, because no person taught you that. My Father in heaven showed you who I am.
MT
16:18
So I tell you, you are Peter.(ay) On this rock I will build my church, and the power of death will not be able to defeat it.
MT
16:19
I will give you the keys of the kingdom of heaven; the things you don’t allow on earth will be the things that God does not allow, and the things you allow on earth will be the things that God allows.”
MT
16:20
Then Jesus warned his followers not to tell anyone he was the Christ.
MT
16:21
From that time on Jesus began telling his followers that he must go to Jerusalem, where the Jewish elders, the leading priests, and the teachers of the law would make him suffer many things. He told them he must be killed and then be raised from the dead on the third day.
MT
16:22
Peter took Jesus aside and told him not to talk like that. He said, “God save you from those things, Lord! Those things will never happen to you!”
MT
16:23
Then Jesus said to Peter, “Go away from me, Satan!(az) You are not helping me! You don’t care about the things of God, but only about the things people think are important.”
LK
9:23
Jesus said to all of them, “If people want to follow me, they must give up the things they want. They must be willing to give up their lives daily to follow me.
LK
9:24
Those who want to save their lives will give up true life. But those who give up their lives for me will have true life.
LK
9:25
It is worthless to have the whole world if they themselves are destroyed or lost.
MK
8:38
The people who live now are living in a sinful and evil time. If people are ashamed of me and my teaching, the Son of Man will be ashamed of them when he comes with his Father’s glory and with the holy angels.”
Default Mt 16:13-27 Mk 8:27-38 Lk 9:18-26
MT
16:13
When Jesus came to the area of Caesarea Philippi, he asked his followers, “Who do people say the Son of Man is?”
MT
16:14
They answered, “Some say you are John the Baptist. Others say you are Elijah, and still others say you are Jeremiah or one of the prophets.”
MT
16:15
Then Jesus asked them, “And who do you say I am?”
MT
16:16
Simon Peter answered, “You are the Christ, the Son of the living God.”
MT
16:17
Jesus answered, “You are blessed, Simon son of Jonah, because no person taught you that. My Father in heaven showed you who I am.
MT
16:18
So I tell you, you are Peter.(ay) On this rock I will build my church, and the power of death will not be able to defeat it.
MT
16:19
I will give you the keys of the kingdom of heaven; the things you don’t allow on earth will be the things that God does not allow, and the things you allow on earth will be the things that God allows.”
MT
16:20
Then Jesus warned his followers not to tell anyone he was the Christ.
MT
16:21
From that time on Jesus began telling his followers that he must go to Jerusalem, where the Jewish elders, the leading priests, and the teachers of the law would make him suffer many things. He told them he must be killed and then be raised from the dead on the third day.
MT
16:22
Peter took Jesus aside and told him not to talk like that. He said, “God save you from those things, Lord! Those things will never happen to you!”
MT
16:23
Then Jesus said to Peter, “Go away from me, Satan!(az) You are not helping me! You don’t care about the things of God, but only about the things people think are important.”
MT
16:24
Then Jesus said to his followers, “If people want to follow me, they must give up the things they want. They must be willing even to give up their lives to follow me.
MT
16:25
Those who want to save their lives will give up true life, and those who give up their lives for me will have true life.
MT
16:26
It is worthless to have the whole world if they lose their souls. They could never pay enough to buy back their souls.
MT
16:27
The Son of Man will come again with his Father’s glory and with his angels. At that time, he will reward them for what they have done.
Default Mt 16:13-27 Mk 8:27-38 Lk 9:18-26
MK
8:27
Jesus and his followers went to the towns around Caesarea Philippi. While they were traveling, Jesus asked them, “Who do people say I am?”
MK
8:28
They answered, “Some say you are John the Baptist. Others say you are Elijah,(aa) and others say you are one of the prophets.”
MK
8:29
Then Jesus asked, “But who do you say I am?” Peter answered, “You are the Christ.”
MK
8:30
Jesus warned his followers not to tell anyone who he was.
MK
8:31
Then Jesus began to teach them that the Son of Man must suffer many things and that he would be rejected by the Jewish elders, the leading priests, and the teachers of the law. He told them that the Son of Man must be killed and then rise from the dead after three days.
MK
8:32
Jesus told them plainly what would happen. Then Peter took Jesus aside and began to tell him not to talk like that.
MK
8:33
But Jesus turned and looked at his followers. Then he told Peter not to talk that way. He said, “Go away from me, Satan!(ab) You don’t care about the things of God, but only about things people think are important.”
MK
8:34
Then Jesus called the crowd to him, along with his followers. He said, “If people want to follow me, they must give up the things they want. They must be willing even to give up their lives to follow me.
MK
8:35
Those who want to save their lives will give up true life. But those who give up their lives for me and for the Good News will have true life.
MK
8:36
It is worthless to have the whole world if they lose their souls.
MK
8:37
They could never pay enough to buy back their souls.
MK
8:38
The people who live now are living in a sinful and evil time. If people are ashamed of me and my teaching, the Son of Man will be ashamed of them when he comes with his Father’s glory and with the holy angels.”
Default Mt 16:13-27 Mk 8:27-38 Lk 9:18-26
LK
9:18
One time when Jesus was praying alone, his followers were with him, and he asked them, “Who do the people say I am?”
LK
9:19
They answered, “Some say you are John the Baptist. Others say you are Elijah.(ad) And others say you are one of the prophets from long ago who has come back to life.”
LK
9:20
Then Jesus asked, “But who do you say I am?” Peter answered, “You are the Christ from God.”
LK
9:21
Jesus warned them not to tell anyone, saying,
LK
9:22
“The Son of Man must suffer many things. He will be rejected by the Jewish elders, the leading priests, and the teachers of the law. He will be killed and after three days will be raised from the dead.”
LK
9:23
Jesus said to all of them, “If people want to follow me, they must give up the things they want. They must be willing to give up their lives daily to follow me.
LK
9:24
Those who want to save their lives will give up true life. But those who give up their lives for me will have true life.
LK
9:25
It is worthless to have the whole world if they themselves are destroyed or lost.
LK
9:26
If people are ashamed of me and my teaching, then the Son of Man will be ashamed of them when he comes in his glory and with the glory of the Father and the holy angels.
Week 32 | Some Of You Will See The Kingdom Of God Before They Die

16:28
I tell you the truth, some people standing here will see the Son of Man coming with his kingdom before they die.”

16:28
I tell you the truth, some people standing here will see the Son of Man coming with his kingdom before they die.”

9:1
Then Jesus said to the people, “I tell you the truth, some people standing here will see the kingdom of God come with power before they die.”

I tell you the truth, some people standing here will see the kingdom of God before they die.”
Week 33 | Day Of Atonement
Mt 17:1-13 Mk 9:2-13 Lk 9:28-36
Default Mt 17:1-13 Mk 9:2-13 Lk 9:28-36
MT
17:1
Six days later, Jesus took Peter, James, and John, the brother of James, up on a high mountain by themselves.
LK
9:29
While Jesus was praying, the appearance of his face changed, and his clothes became shining white.
LK
9:30
Then two men, Moses and Elijah,(ae) were talking with Jesus.
LK
9:31
They appeared in heavenly glory, talking about his departure which he would soon bring about in Jerusalem.
LK
9:32
Peter and the others were very sleepy, but when they awoke fully, they saw the glory of Jesus and the two men standing with him.
LK
9:33
When Moses and Elijah were about to leave, Peter said to Jesus, “Master, it is good that we are here. Let us make three tents - one for you, one for Moses, and one for Elijah.” (Peter did not know what he was talking about.)
LK
9:34
While he was saying these things, a cloud came and covered them, and they became afraid as the cloud covered them.
LK
9:35
A voice came from the cloud, saying, “This is my Son, whom I have chosen. Listen to him!”
MT
17:6
When his followers heard the voice, they were so frightened they fell to the ground.
MT
17:7
But Jesus went to them and touched them and said, “Stand up. Don’t be afraid.”
MT
17:8
When they looked up, they saw Jesus was now alone.
MT
17:9
As they were coming down the mountain, Jesus commanded them not to tell anyone about what they had seen until the Son of Man had risen from the dead.
MT
17:10
Then his followers asked him, “Why do the teachers of the law say that Elijah must come first?”
MT
17:11
Jesus answered, “They are right to say that Elijah is coming and that he will make everything the way it should be.
MT
17:12
But I tell you that Elijah has already come, and they did not recognize him. They did to him whatever they wanted to do. It will be the same with the Son of Man; those same people will make the Son of Man suffer.”
MT
17:13
Then the followers understood that Jesus was talking about John the Baptist.
Default Mt 17:1-13 Mk 9:2-13 Lk 9:28-36
MT
17:1
Six days later, Jesus took Peter, James, and John, the brother of James, up on a high mountain by themselves.
MT
17:2
While they watched, Jesus’ appearance was changed; his face became bright like the sun, and his clothes became white as light.
MT
17:3
Then Moses and Elijah(ba) appeared to them, talking with Jesus.
MT
17:4
Peter said to Jesus, “Lord, it is good that we are here. If you want, I will put up three tents here - one for you, one for Moses, and one for Elijah.”
MT
17:5
While Peter was talking, a bright cloud covered them. A voice came from the cloud and said, “This is my Son, whom I love, and I am very pleased with him. Listen to him!”
MT
17:6
When his followers heard the voice, they were so frightened they fell to the ground.
MT
17:7
But Jesus went to them and touched them and said, “Stand up. Don’t be afraid.”
MT
17:8
When they looked up, they saw Jesus was now alone.
MT
17:9
As they were coming down the mountain, Jesus commanded them not to tell anyone about what they had seen until the Son of Man had risen from the dead.
MT
17:10
Then his followers asked him, “Why do the teachers of the law say that Elijah must come first?”
MT
17:11
Jesus answered, “They are right to say that Elijah is coming and that he will make everything the way it should be.
MT
17:12
But I tell you that Elijah has already come, and they did not recognize him. They did to him whatever they wanted to do. It will be the same with the Son of Man; those same people will make the Son of Man suffer.”
MT
17:13
Then the followers understood that Jesus was talking about John the Baptist.
Default Mt 17:1-13 Mk 9:2-13 Lk 9:28-36
MK
9:2
Six days later, Jesus took Peter, James, and John up on a high mountain by themselves. While they watched, Jesus’ appearance was changed.
MK
9:3
His clothes became shining white, whiter than any person could make them.
MK
9:4
Then Elijah and Moses(ac) appeared to them, talking with Jesus.
MK
9:5
Peter said to Jesus, “Teacher, it is good that we are here. Let us make three tents - one for you, one for Moses, and one for Elijah.”
MK
9:6
Peter did not know what to say, because he and the others were so frightened.
MK
9:7
Then a cloud came and covered them, and a voice came from the cloud, saying, “This is my Son, whom I love. Listen to him!”
MK
9:8
Suddenly Peter, James, and John looked around, but they saw only Jesus there alone with them.
MK
9:9
As they were coming down the mountain, Jesus commanded them not to tell anyone about what they had seen until the Son of Man had risen from the dead.
MK
9:10
So the followers obeyed Jesus, but they discussed what he meant about rising from the dead.
MK
9:11
Then they asked Jesus, “Why do the teachers of the law say that Elijah must come first?”
MK
9:12
Jesus answered, “They are right to say that Elijah must come first and make everything the way it should be. But why does the Scripture say that the Son of Man will suffer much and that people will treat him as if he were nothing?
MK
9:13
I tell you that Elijah has already come. And people did to him whatever they wanted to do, just as the Scriptures said it would happen.”
Default Mt 17:1-13 Mk 9:2-13 Lk 9:28-36
LK
9:28
About eight days after Jesus said these things, he took Peter, John, and James and went up on a mountain to pray.
LK
9:29
While Jesus was praying, the appearance of his face changed, and his clothes became shining white.
LK
9:30
Then two men, Moses and Elijah,(ae) were talking with Jesus.
LK
9:31
They appeared in heavenly glory, talking about his departure which he would soon bring about in Jerusalem.
LK
9:32
Peter and the others were very sleepy, but when they awoke fully, they saw the glory of Jesus and the two men standing with him.
LK
9:33
When Moses and Elijah were about to leave, Peter said to Jesus, “Master, it is good that we are here. Let us make three tents - one for you, one for Moses, and one for Elijah.” (Peter did not know what he was talking about.)
LK
9:34
While he was saying these things, a cloud came and covered them, and they became afraid as the cloud covered them.
LK
9:35
A voice came from the cloud, saying, “This is my Son, whom I have chosen. Listen to him!”
LK
9:36
When the voice finished speaking, only Jesus was there. Peter, John, and James said nothing and told no one at that time what they had seen.
Week 33 | Forcing Out A Difficult Evil Spirit
Mt 17:14-21 Mk 9:14-29 Lk 9:37-43
Default Mt 17:14-21 Mk 9:14-29 Lk 9:37-43
LK
9:37
The next day, when they came down from the mountain, a large crowd met Jesus.
MK
9:16
Jesus asked, “What are you arguing about?”
MK
9:17
A man answered, “Teacher, I brought my son to you. He has an evil spirit in him that stops him from talking.
MK
9:18
When the spirit attacks him, it throws him on the ground. Then my son foams at the mouth, grinds his teeth, and becomes very stiff. I asked your followers to force the evil spirit out, but they couldn’t.”
MK
9:19
Jesus answered, “You people have no faith. How long must I stay with you? How long must I put up with you? Bring the boy to me.”
MK
9:20
So the followers brought him to Jesus. As soon as the evil spirit saw Jesus, it made the boy lose control of himself, and he fell down and rolled on the ground, foaming at the mouth.
MK
9:21
Jesus asked the boy’s father, “How long has this been happening?” The father answered, “Since he was very young.
MK
9:22
The spirit often throws him into a fire or into water to kill him. If you can do anything for him, please have pity on us and help us.”
MK
9:23
Jesus said to the father, “You said, ‘If you can!’ All things are possible for the one who believes.”
MK
9:24
Immediately the father cried out, “I do believe! Help me to believe more!”
MK
9:25
When Jesus saw that a crowd was quickly gathering, he ordered the evil spirit, saying, “You spirit that makes people unable to hear or speak, I command you to come out of this boy and never enter him again!”
MK
9:26
The evil spirit screamed and caused the boy to fall on the ground again. Then the spirit came out. The boy looked as if he were dead, and many people said, “He is dead!”
MK
9:27
But Jesus took hold of the boy’s hand and helped him to stand up.
MK
9:28
When Jesus went into the house, his followers began asking him privately, “Why couldn’t we force that evil spirit out?”
MT
17:20
Jesus answered, “Because your faith is too small. I tell you the truth, if your faith is as big as a mustard seed, you can say to this mountain, ‘Move from here to there,’ and it will move. All things will be possible for you. [
MT
17:21
That kind of spirit comes out only if you use prayer and fasting.]”(bc)
Default Mt 17:14-21 Mk 9:14-29 Lk 9:37-43
MT
17:14
When Jesus and his followers came back to the crowd, a man came to Jesus and bowed before him.
MT
17:15
The man said, “Lord, have mercy on my son. He has epilepsy(bb) and is suffering very much, because he often falls into the fire or into the water.
MT
17:16
I brought him to your followers, but they could not cure him.”
MT
17:17
Jesus answered, “You people have no faith, and your lives are all wrong. How long must I put up with you? How long must I continue to be patient with you? Bring the boy here.”
MT
17:18
Jesus commanded the demon inside the boy. Then the demon came out, and the boy was healed from that time on.
MT
17:19
The followers came to Jesus when he was alone and asked, “Why couldn’t we force the demon out?”
MT
17:20
Jesus answered, “Because your faith is too small. I tell you the truth, if your faith is as big as a mustard seed, you can say to this mountain, ‘Move from here to there,’ and it will move. All things will be possible for you. [
MT
17:21
That kind of spirit comes out only if you use prayer and fasting.]”(bc)
Default Mt 17:14-21 Mk 9:14-29 Lk 9:37-43
MK
9:14
When Jesus, Peter, James, and John came back to the other followers, they saw a great crowd around them and the teachers of the law arguing with them.
MK
9:15
But as soon as the crowd saw Jesus, the people were surprised and ran to welcome him.
MK
9:16
Jesus asked, “What are you arguing about?”
MK
9:17
A man answered, “Teacher, I brought my son to you. He has an evil spirit in him that stops him from talking.
MK
9:18
When the spirit attacks him, it throws him on the ground. Then my son foams at the mouth, grinds his teeth, and becomes very stiff. I asked your followers to force the evil spirit out, but they couldn’t.”
MK
9:19
Jesus answered, “You people have no faith. How long must I stay with you? How long must I put up with you? Bring the boy to me.”
MK
9:20
So the followers brought him to Jesus. As soon as the evil spirit saw Jesus, it made the boy lose control of himself, and he fell down and rolled on the ground, foaming at the mouth.
MK
9:21
Jesus asked the boy’s father, “How long has this been happening?” The father answered, “Since he was very young.
MK
9:22
The spirit often throws him into a fire or into water to kill him. If you can do anything for him, please have pity on us and help us.”
MK
9:23
Jesus said to the father, “You said, ‘If you can!’ All things are possible for the one who believes.”
MK
9:24
Immediately the father cried out, “I do believe! Help me to believe more!”
MK
9:25
When Jesus saw that a crowd was quickly gathering, he ordered the evil spirit, saying, “You spirit that makes people unable to hear or speak, I command you to come out of this boy and never enter him again!”
MK
9:26
The evil spirit screamed and caused the boy to fall on the ground again. Then the spirit came out. The boy looked as if he were dead, and many people said, “He is dead!”
MK
9:27
But Jesus took hold of the boy’s hand and helped him to stand up.
MK
9:28
When Jesus went into the house, his followers began asking him privately, “Why couldn’t we force that evil spirit out?”
MK
9:29
Jesus answered, “That kind of spirit can only be forced out by prayer.”(ad)
Default Mt 17:14-21 Mk 9:14-29 Lk 9:37-43
LK
9:37
The next day, when they came down from the mountain, a large crowd met Jesus.
LK
9:38
A man in the crowd shouted to him, “Teacher, please come and look at my son, because he is my only child.
LK
9:39
An evil spirit seizes my son, and suddenly he screams. It causes him to lose control of himself and foam at the mouth. The evil spirit keeps on hurting him and almost never leaves him.
LK
9:40
I begged your followers to force the evil spirit out, but they could not do it.”
LK
9:41
Jesus answered, “You people have no faith, and your lives are all wrong. How long must I stay with you and put up with you? Bring your son here.”
LK
9:42
While the boy was coming, the demon threw him on the ground and made him lose control of himself. But Jesus gave a strong command to the evil spirit and healed the boy and gave him back to his father.
LK
9:43
All the people were amazed at the great power of God. Jesus Talks About His Death While everyone was wondering about all that Jesus did, he said to his followers,
Week 33 | Back To Galilee

Week 33 | Jesus Talks About His Death
Mt 17:22-23 Mk 9:30-32 Lk 9:43-45 Jn 7:1-1
Default Mt 17:22-23 Mk 9:30-32 Lk 9:43-45 Jn 7:1-1
MK
9:30
Then Jesus and his followers left that place and went through Galilee. He didn’t want anyone to know where he was,
MK
9:31
because he was teaching his followers. He said to them, “The Son of Man will be handed over to people, and they will kill him. After three days, he will rise from the dead.”
LK
9:45
But the followers did not understand what this meant; the meaning was hidden from them so they could not understand. But they were afraid to ask Jesus about it. Who Is the Greatest?
Default Mt 17:22-23 Mk 9:30-32 Lk 9:43-45 Jn 7:1-1
MT
17:22
While Jesus’ followers were gathering in Galilee, he said to them, “The Son of Man will be handed over to people,
MT
17:23
and they will kill him. But on the third day he will be raised from the dead.” And the followers were filled with sadness.

9:31
because he was teaching his followers. He said to them, “The Son of Man will be handed over to people, and they will kill him. After three days, he will rise from the dead.”
MK
9:32

9:43

LK
9:44

LK
9:45

Default Mt 17:22-23 Mk 9:30-32 Lk 9:43-45 Jn 7:1-1
JN
7:1
After this, Jesus traveled around Galilee. He did not want to travel in Judea, because some evil people there wanted to kill him.
Week 33 | Temple Tax
Mt 17:24-27
Mt 17:24-27
MT
17:24
When Jesus and his followers came to Capernaum, the men who collected the Temple tax came to Peter. They asked, “Does your teacher pay the Temple tax?”
MT
17:25
Peter answered, “Yes, Jesus pays the tax.” Peter went into the house, but before he could speak, Jesus said to him, “What do you think? The kings of the earth collect different kinds of taxes. But who pays the taxes-the king’s children or others?”
MT
17:26
Peter answered, “Other people pay the taxes.” Jesus said to Peter, “Then the children of the king don’t have to pay taxes.
MT
17:27
But we don’t want to upset these tax collectors. So go to the lake and fish. After you catch the first fish, open its mouth and you will find a coin. Take that coin and give it to the tax collectors for you and me.”
Week 33 | Jesus’ Brothers Don’t Believe
Jn 7:2-9
Default Jn 7:2-9
JN
7:2
It was time for the Feast of Shelters.
JN
7:3
So Jesus’ brothers said to him, “You should leave here and go to Judea so your followers there can see the miracles you do.
JN
7:4
Anyone who wants to be well known does not hide what he does. If you are doing these things, show yourself to the world.”
JN
7:5
(Even Jesus’ brothers did not believe in him.)
JN
7:6
Jesus said to his brothers, “The right time for me has not yet come, but any time is right for you.
JN
7:7
The world cannot hate you, but it hates me, because I tell it the evil things it does.
JN
7:8
So you go to the feast. I will not go yet(aa) to this feast, because the right time for me has not yet come.”
JN
7:9
After saying this, Jesus stayed in Galilee.

7:2
It was time for the Feast of Shelters.
JN
7:3
So Jesus’ brothers said to him, “You should leave here and go to Judea so your followers there can see the miracles you do.
JN
7:4
Anyone who wants to be well known does not hide what he does. If you are doing these things, show yourself to the world.”
JN
7:5
(Even Jesus’ brothers did not believe in him.)
JN
7:6
Jesus said to his brothers, “The right time for me has not yet come, but any time is right for you.
JN
7:7
The world cannot hate you, but it hates me, because I tell it the evil things it does.
JN
7:8
So you go to the feast. I will not go yet(aa) to this feast, because the right time for me has not yet come.”
JN
7:9

Week 33 | Who Is The Greatest?
Mt 18:1-5 Mk 9:33-37 Lk 9:46-48
Default Mt 18:1-5 Mk 9:33-37 Lk 9:46-48
MK
9:33
Jesus and his followers went to Capernaum. When they went into a house there, he asked them, “What were you arguing about on the road?”
MK
9:34
But the followers did not answer, because their argument on the road was about which one of them was the greatest.
MK
9:35
Jesus sat down and called the twelve apostles to him. He said, “Whoever wants to be the most important must be last of all and servant of all.”
MK
9:36
Then Jesus took a small child and had him stand among them. Taking the child in his arms, he said,
MK
9:37
“Whoever accepts a child like this in my name accepts me. And whoever accepts me accepts the One who sent me.”
Default Mt 18:1-5 Mk 9:33-37 Lk 9:46-48
MT
18:1
At that time the followers came to Jesus and asked, “Who is greatest in the kingdom of heaven?”
MT
18:2
Jesus called a little child to him and stood the child before his followers.
MT
18:3
Then he said, “I tell you the truth, you must change and become like little children. Otherwise, you will never enter the kingdom of heaven.
MT
18:4
The greatest person in the kingdom of heaven is the one who makes himself humble like this child.
MT
18:5
“Whoever accepts a child in my name accepts me.
Default Mt 18:1-5 Mk 9:33-37 Lk 9:46-48
MK
9:33
Jesus and his followers went to Capernaum. When they went into a house there, he asked them, “What were you arguing about on the road?”
MK
9:34
But the followers did not answer, because their argument on the road was about which one of them was the greatest.
MK
9:35
Jesus sat down and called the twelve apostles to him. He said, “Whoever wants to be the most important must be last of all and servant of all.”
MK
9:36
Then Jesus took a small child and had him stand among them. Taking the child in his arms, he said,
MK
9:37
“Whoever accepts a child like this in my name accepts me. And whoever accepts me accepts the One who sent me.”
Default Mt 18:1-5 Mk 9:33-37 Lk 9:46-48
LK
9:46
Jesus’ followers began to have an argument about which one of them was the greatest.
LK
9:47
Jesus knew what they were thinking, so he took a little child and stood the child beside him.
LK
9:48
Then Jesus said, “Whoever accepts this little child in my name accepts me. And whoever accepts me accepts the One who sent me, because whoever is least among you all is really the greatest.”
Week 33 | Anyone Not Against Us Is For Us
Mk 9:38-40 Lk 9:49-50
Default Mk 9:38-40 Lk 9:49-50
MK
9:38
Then John said, “Teacher, we saw someone using your name to force demons out of a person. We told him to stop, because he does not belong to our group.”
MK
9:39
But Jesus said, “Don’t stop him, because anyone who uses my name to do powerful things will not easily say evil things about me.
MK
9:40
Whoever is not against us is with us.
Default Mk 9:38-40 Lk 9:49-50
MK
9:38
Then John said, “Teacher, we saw someone using your name to force demons out of a person. We told him to stop, because he does not belong to our group.”
MK
9:39
But Jesus said, “Don’t stop him, because anyone who uses my name to do powerful things will not easily say evil things about me.
MK
9:40
Whoever is not against us is with us.
Default Mk 9:38-40 Lk 9:49-50
LK
9:49
John answered, “Master, we saw someone using your name to force demons out of people. We told him to stop, because he does not belong to our group.”
LK
9:50
But Jesus said to him, “Don’t stop him, because whoever is not against you is for you.”
Week 33 | Don't Cause Stumble
Mt 18:6-9 Mk 9:42-49 Lk 17:1-2
Default Mt 18:6-9 Mk 9:42-49 Lk 17:1-2
MT
18:6
If one of these little children believes in me, and someone causes that child to sin, it would be better for that person to have a large stone tied around the neck and be drowned in the sea.
MT
18:7
How terrible for the people of the world because of the things that cause them to sin. Such things will happen, but how terrible for the one who causes them to happen!
MT
18:8
If your hand or your foot causes you to sin, cut it off and throw it away. It is better for you to lose part of your body and live forever than to have two hands and two feet and be thrown into the fire that burns forever.
MT
18:9
If your eye causes you to sin, take it out and throw it away. It is better for you to have only one eye and live forever than to have two eyes and be thrown into the fire of hell.
MK
9:49
Every person will be salted with fire.
Default Mt 18:6-9 Mk 9:42-49 Lk 17:1-2
MT
18:6
If one of these little children believes in me, and someone causes that child to sin, it would be better for that person to have a large stone tied around the neck and be drowned in the sea.
MT
18:7
How terrible for the people of the world because of the things that cause them to sin. Such things will happen, but how terrible for the one who causes them to happen!
MT
18:8
If your hand or your foot causes you to sin, cut it off and throw it away. It is better for you to lose part of your body and live forever than to have two hands and two feet and be thrown into the fire that burns forever.
MT
18:9
If your eye causes you to sin, take it out and throw it away. It is better for you to have only one eye and live forever than to have two eyes and be thrown into the fire of hell.
Default Mt 18:6-9 Mk 9:42-49 Lk 17:1-2
MK
9:42
“If one of these little children believes in me, and someone causes that child to sin, it would be better for that person to have a large stone tied around his neck and be drowned in the sea.
MK
9:43
If your hand causes you to sin, cut it off. It is better for you to lose part of your body and live forever than to have two hands and go to hell, where the fire never goes out. [
MK
9:44
In hell the worm does not die; the fire is never put out.](ae)
MK
9:45
If your foot causes you to sin, cut it off. It is better for you to lose part of your body and to live forever than to have two feet and be thrown into hell. [
MK
9:46
In hell the worm does not die; the fire is never put out.](af)
MK
9:47
If your eye causes you to sin, take it out. It is better for you to enter the kingdom of God with only one eye than to have two eyes and be thrown into hell.
MK
9:48
In hell the worm does not die; the fire is never put out.
MK
9:49
Every person will be salted with fire.
Default Mt 18:6-9 Mk 9:42-49 Lk 17:1-2
LK
17:1
Jesus said to his followers, “Things that cause people to sin will happen, but how terrible for the person who causes them to happen!
LK
17:2
It would be better for you to be thrown into the sea with a large stone around your neck than to cause one of these little ones to sin.
